articles.headline: Finding Financial Advice in an Age of Bad Behavior
articles.snippet: An organization of financial advisers says that a few reported rotten apples should not taint the entire group.
articles.abstract: An organization of financial advisers says that a few reported rotten apples should not taint the entire group.
articles.lead_paragraph: The reports about crooked behavior in the world of financial planning just keep getting worse.

articles.headline: Obama Pins Mideast Hope on Limiting Settlements
articles.snippet: The Obama administration has selected Israeli settlement building in occupied lands as the issue that could begin to untie the Gordian knot of the conflict.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration has selected Israeli settlement building in occupied lands as the issue that could begin to untie the Gordian knot of the conflict.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM  Iran seems to be hurtling toward nuclear weapons capacity, Hezbollah could win Sunday’s election in Lebanon and Hamas is smuggling long-range rockets into Gaza again. So why is President Obama focusing such attention on the building of homes by Israeli Jews in the West Bank?

articles.headline: New Scrutiny of Judge’s Most Controversial Case
articles.snippet: A case involving firefighters’ discrimination claims is likely to attract questions at the Supreme Court confirmation of Judge Sonia Sotomayor.
articles.abstract: A case involving firefighters’ discrimination claims is likely to attract questions at the Supreme Court confirmation of Judge Sonia Sotomayor.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Near the end of a long and heated appeals court argument over whether New Haven was entitled to throw out a promotional exam because black firefighters had performed poorly on it, a lawyer for white firefighters challenging that decision made a point that bothered Judge Sonia Sotomayor.

articles.headline: Poking Holes in a Theory on Markets
articles.snippet: The efficient market hypothesis, which argues that the stock market is essentially rational, is taking serious hits, and one analyst says it is at the root of the financial crisis.
articles.abstract: The efficient market hypothesis, which argues that the stock market is essentially rational, is taking serious hits, and one analyst says it is at the root of the financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: For some months now, Jeremy Grantham, a respected market strategist with GMO, an institutional asset management company, has been railing about  of all things  the efficient market hypothesis.

articles.headline: U.S. May Permit 9/11 Guilty Pleas in Capital Cases
articles.snippet: The Obama administration is considering a change in the law for Guantánamo military commissions that could let prosecutors avoid trials that would air details of interrogation techniques.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration is considering a change in the law for Guantánamo military commissions that could let prosecutors avoid trials that would air details of interrogation techniques.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration is considering a change in the law for the military commissions at the prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, that would clear the way for detainees facing the death penalty to plead guilty without a full trial.

articles.headline: Millions Face Blank Screens in TV Switch
articles.snippet: Despite government efforts to promote the switch to digital signals and a delay of four months in the schedule, three million homes are unprepared.
articles.abstract: Despite government efforts to promote the switch to digital signals and a delay of four months in the schedule, three million homes are unprepared.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Millions of households will lose television reception next week when about 1,000 broadcasters around the nation shut off their analog signals and complete their conversion to digital programming, federal officials say.

articles.headline: Regulators Push for Change at Two Troubled Big Banks
articles.snippet: With Bank of America and Citigroup due to report on their progress under the bailout, it’s uncertain whether their top leaders can keep their jobs.
articles.abstract: With Bank of America and Citigroup due to report on their progress under the bailout, it’s uncertain whether their top leaders can keep their jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: With a crucial deadline looming in the federal bank bailout program, Washington regulators are pressing some unwelcome prescriptions upon two of the nation’s largest lenders.
articles.byline: By Edmund L. Andrews and Louise Story

articles.headline: Discredited Research Study Stuns an Ex-Army Doctor’s Colleagues
articles.snippet: Officials uncovered an apparent case of falsified research by a doctor who had befriended another physician at Walter Reed, and seemingly attached that doctor’s name to his study.
articles.abstract: Officials uncovered an apparent case of falsified research by a doctor who had befriended another physician at Walter Reed, and seemingly attached that doctor’s name to his study.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dr. Romney C. Andersen, a Walter Reed Army Medical Center surgeon, was surprised last summer when his neighbor, a fellow doctor, congratulated him on a new medical journal study bearing his name.
articles.byline: By Barry Meier and Duff Wilson

articles.headline: A Blagojevich Tries Reality TV
articles.snippet: Patricia Blagojevich, best known for her foul-mouthed tirades captured on federal wiretaps of her husband, is part of the cast on a new NBC reality series.
articles.abstract: Patricia Blagojevich, best known for her foul-mouthed tirades captured on federal wiretaps of her husband, is part of the cast on a new NBC reality series.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  Around here, Patricia Blagojevich is best known for her foul-mouthed tirades captured on federal wiretaps last year when her husband, Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich, was under investigation.

articles.headline: Moscow Crime Reporter, Facing His Obituary Daily
articles.snippet: Sergei Kanev, a bold journalist, says that only by facing the truth can Russians retake their country.
articles.abstract: Sergei Kanev, a bold journalist, says that only by facing the truth can Russians retake their country.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  After the most recent attack on Sergei Kanev  attempted strangulation with a wire, in his apartment’s stairwell here  his editor visited him and delicately suggested that he take a six-month sabbatical from crime reporting, in America.

articles.headline: For Sotomayor and Thomas, Paths Diverge at Race
articles.snippet: Judge Sonia Sotomayor and Justice Clarence Thomas have walked parallel paths, but they stand at opposite poles of thinking about race, identity and opportunity.
articles.abstract: Judge Sonia Sotomayor and Justice Clarence Thomas have walked parallel paths, but they stand at opposite poles of thinking about race, identity and opportunity.
articles.lead_paragraph: If Judge Sonia Sotomayor joins Justice Clarence Thomas on the Supreme Court, they may find that they have far more than a job title in common.
articles.byline: By Jodi Kantor and David Gonzalez

articles.headline: U.S. Lawyers Agreed on Legality of Brutal Tactic
articles.snippet: Some Justice Department lawyers who argued against using harsh interrogation techniques still went along with a 2005 legal opinion asserting that the methods themselves were lawful.
articles.abstract: Some Justice Department lawyers who argued against using harsh interrogation techniques still went along with a 2005 legal opinion asserting that the methods themselves were lawful.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When Justice Department lawyers engaged in a sharp internal debate in 2005 over brutal interrogation techniques, even some who believed that using tough tactics was a serious mistake agreed on a basic point: the methods themselves were legal.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and David Johnston

articles.headline: If All Doctors Had More Time to Listen
articles.snippet: Instead of waiting for health care reform, some doctors are cutting administrative costs, seeing fewer patients and focusing on prevention.
articles.abstract: Instead of waiting for health care reform, some doctors are cutting administrative costs, seeing fewer patients and focusing on prevention.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN Dr. José Batlle met his 93-year-old patient in her small Bronx apartment, she didn’t have much furniture beyond a small TV, a sofa and a wheelchair. What she did have in abundance were pills  15 types from a variety of doctors, including a pulmonologist, a cardiologist and a gerontologist. He discovered that some medicines had expired, others were unnecessary and some were dangerous if taken together.

articles.headline: Obama to Forge a Greater Role on Health Care
articles.snippet: President Obama is preparing a push for legislation that will include speeches, town-hall-style meetings and much deeper engagement with lawmakers, officials say.
articles.abstract: President Obama is preparing a push for legislation that will include speeches, town-hall-style meetings and much deeper engagement with lawmakers, officials say.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  After months of insisting he would leave the details to Congress, President Obama has concluded that he must exert greater control over the health care debate and is preparing an intense push for legislation that will include speeches, town-hall-style meetings and much deeper engagement with lawmakers, senior White House officials say.

articles.headline: Will Warner Grow Tired of New Line, Its Pet Indie?
articles.snippet: Now folded into Warner Brothers, New Line Cinema is surprising some as it manages to hang on to its indie flair.
articles.abstract: Now folded into Warner Brothers, New Line Cinema is surprising some as it manages to hang on to its indie flair.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES

articles.headline: It May Be ‘Bon Voyage’ for a Travel Site’s Fee
articles.snippet: A stream of online revenue for travel companies is facing many challenges after a court ruled last month that Expedia’s fee disclosures breached its contract with customers.
articles.abstract: A stream of online revenue for travel companies is facing many challenges after a court ruled last month that Expedia’s fee disclosures breached its contract with customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: FOR years, online travel companies like Expedia, Orbitz, Travelocity and others have successfully defended one of their most profitable practices: capturing the sizable difference between what they charge customers for taxes on hotel rooms and taxes the companies actually pay.

articles.headline: In One City, Two Soirees Ages Apart
articles.snippet: In Midtown, a farewell to an era of print’s dominance, while downtown, the new titans celebrated their arrival.
articles.abstract: In Midtown, a farewell to an era of print’s dominance, while downtown, the new titans celebrated their arrival.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the Century Club in New York last Wednesday, more than a hundred people, many of them journalists, gathered for a farewell to Peter Kaplan, the outgoing editor of The New York Observer, a newspaper that served as a wiring diagram in a city where printed information and power have historically held hands.

articles.headline: Weinstein Company Takes Step to Ease Debt
articles.snippet: The company, which has yet to have a film reach $100 million at the domestic box office, has hired the financial consultant Miller Buckfire, which says it specializes in “overleveraged” companies.
articles.abstract: The company, which has yet to have a film reach $100 million at the domestic box office, has hired the financial consultant Miller Buckfire, which says it specializes in “overleveraged” companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  At a gathering of the Oscar nominees in February, Harvey Weinstein was greeted by an acquaintance who called him the “the guy who knows this game” better than anyone.

articles.headline: Victims of Madoff Seek Claims Overhaul
articles.snippet: Customers say that they should be given credit for the full value of the securities shown on the last account statements they received before their investor’s arrest.
articles.abstract: Customers say that they should be given credit for the full value of the securities shown on the last account statements they received before their investor’s arrest.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a step that would substantially increase the price tag for Bernard L. Madoff’s long-running Ponzi scheme, lawyers for a group of his victims are asking a federal bankruptcy judge to reject the way their losses in the fraud are being calculated.

articles.headline: The Woman in Charge of Reality Shows at Spike TV
articles.snippet: After Comedy Central and the Sci Fi Channel, Sharon Levy is out to refocus the channel with a reputation as a sort of Maxim magazine for television.
articles.abstract: After Comedy Central and the Sci Fi Channel, Sharon Levy is out to refocus the channel with a reputation as a sort of Maxim magazine for television.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Sharon Levy is the first to admit that she is not what anyone would call a girl’s girl  just ask her, for example, about her television viewing habits.

articles.headline: After Months of Tension, Globe Votes on Cuts
articles.snippet: There are growing signs that members of the Boston newspaper’s largest union may reject a package of deep cutbacks in wages, benefits and job security.
articles.abstract: There are growing signs that members of the Boston newspaper’s largest union may reject a package of deep cutbacks in wages, benefits and job security.
articles.lead_paragraph: Months of labor acrimony at The Boston Globe will come to a head on Monday, when members of the newspaper’s largest union are to vote on deep cuts in wages, benefits and job security, amid growing signs that they could well reject the deal.

articles.headline: Obama’s Economic Circle Keeps Tensions High
articles.snippet: As advisers struggle with the economic crisis, Lawrence H. Summers is often at the center of heated debates.
articles.abstract: As advisers struggle with the economic crisis, Lawrence H. Summers is often at the center of heated debates.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama was getting his daily economic briefing one recent morning when a fly distracted him. The president swatted and missed, just as the pest buzzed near the shoes of Lawrence H. Summers, the chief White House economic adviser. “Couldn’t you aim a little higher?” deadpanned Christina D. Romer, the chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers.

articles.headline: U.S. Weighs Intercepting North Korean Shipments
articles.snippet: The Obama administration signaled that it was seeking a way to interdict North Korean shipments suspected of carrying weapons or nuclear technology.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration signaled that it was seeking a way to interdict North Korean shipments suspected of carrying weapons or nuclear technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration signaled Sunday that it was seeking a way to interdict, possibly with China’s help, North Korean sea and air shipments suspected of carrying weapons or nuclear technology.

articles.headline: Erratic Afghan Forces Pose Challenge to U.S. Goals
articles.snippet: The Obama administration has made expanding the size and abilities of Afghanistan’s security forces a priority.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration has made expanding the size and abilities of Afghanistan’s security forces a priority.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Afghan foot patrol descended a mountain and slipped through a canyon. Then things went wrong. One Afghan soldier insulted another. And there, exposed on dangerous ground, a scuffle erupted.

articles.headline: U.S. to Propose Wider Oversight of Compensation
articles.snippet: Under the plan, companies that received two rounds of federal bailouts would submit major executive pay changes for approval by a new federal monitor.
articles.abstract: Under the plan, companies that received two rounds of federal bailouts would submit major executive pay changes for approval by a new federal monitor.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration plans to require banks and corporations that have received two rounds of federal bailouts to submit any major executive pay changes for approval by a new federal official who will monitor compensation, according to two government officials.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Hopeful Signs for U.S. in Lebanon Vote
articles.snippet: Gains by the American-aligned coalition could mark a significant shift in regional dynamics, with another major election, in Iran, just four days away.
articles.abstract: Gains by the American-aligned coalition could mark a significant shift in regional dynamics, with another major election, in Iran, just four days away.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon  There were many domestic reasons voters handed an American-backed coalition a victory in Lebanese parliamentary elections on Sunday  but political analysts also attribute it in part to President Obama’s campaign of outreach to the Arab and Muslim world.
